tuv.seg: Right to silence in criminal cases
Ceart chun tosta i gcásanna coiriúla
Bunreacht Na hEireann, (the Irish Constitution) provides protection for everyone in Ireland against self-incrimination
Déanann Bunreacht na hÉireann gach duine in Éirinn a chosaint i gcoinne féin-ionchoirithe
That is, making a statement that might now or later expose you to criminal proceedings
Is é sin ná i gcoinne ráitis a dhéanamh a dhéanfadh imeachtaí coiriúla a thionscnamh ina c(h)oinne
There is also a Constitutional guarantee, that every person accused of a criminal offence in Ireland is innocent until proven guilty
Ina theannta sin, gach duine a cúiseofar i gcion inphíonois in Éirinn is tuigthe é/í a bheith neamhchiontach go dtí go gcruthaítear ciontach é/í, de réir an Bhunreachta
When you are charged by the Gardai with a criminal offence, the responsibility of proving your guilt lies with the prosecution
Nuair a dhéanann na Gardaí duine a chúiseamh i gcion coiriúil, is iad na cúisitheoirí a bhíonn freagrach as a c(h)iontacht a chruthú
Therefore, no responsibility lies with you, the accused, to prove your innocence
Dá bhrí sin, níl orthu a chruthú gur daoine neamhchiontach iad, mar dhaoine cúisithe
There are however two exceptions to this principle:
Tá dhá eisceacht leis seo áfach:
• Where the particular law places a requirement on the accused who raises a statutory defence to prove this defence
• Nuair a bhíonn ar an duine cúisithe, a dhéanann cosaint reachtúil a leagadh amach, a c(h)osaint a chruthú
(For example where you are charged with possession of drugs and the prosecution proved that you actually had the drugs
(Mar shampla, nuair a dhéantar duine a chúiseamh toisc go raibh drugaí ina s(h)eilbh, agus nuair a chruthaíonn na cúisitheoirí go raibh na drugaí ina s(h)eilbh
It is then a legal requirement for you to prove that you did not know that they were drugs
Tá ceanglas dlíthiúil ar an duine a chruthú nach raibh a fhios aige/aici go raibh drugaí ina s(h)eilbh
Otherwise you will be convicted)
Murar féidir leo é seo a dhéanamh, déantar iad a chúiseamh)
• Where you offer a defence of insanity
• Nuair a dhéanann tú pléadáil ghealtachta a thaifeadadh, ní mór duit féin do phléadáil a chruthú
It is then up to you to prove your insanity and this is not a proof that rests with the prosecution
Níl ar na cúisitheoirí a chruthú gurb é seo an cás
The privilege against self-incrimination and the right to silence go hand in hand
Baineann an phribhléid i gcoinne féin-chionntaithe agus an ceart chun tosta lena chéile
They are also closely related to the presumption of innocence
Baineann siad go mór freisin leis an mbarúil gur neamhchiontach thú chomh maith
As the responsibility is placed on the prosecution to prove the guilt of a person it follows that the accused should not be forced to assist the prosecution by being forced to speak
Cé gurb iad na cúisitheoirí atá freagrach as an duine cúisithe a fháil ciontach, níl ar an duine cúisithe aon rud a rá a chabhródh leis na gcúisitheoirí
Your right to silence in Garda custody
Do cheart chun tosta faoi choimeád na nGardaí
If you are arrested and brought to a Garda station, there is an obligation on the arresting Garda to inform you of your general right to remain silent during questioning
Nuair a dhéantar duine a ghabháil agus a thabhairt chun stáisiún na nGardaí, bíonn ar an Garda a chuireann tú faoi ghlas do cheart chun tosta ginearálta le linn ceistiúcháin a chur in iúl duit
This is done by way of a caution
Déantar é seo trí rabhadh a thabhairt duit
The caution states “You are not obliged to say anything unless you wish to do so but anything you say may be taken down in writing and may be used in evidence”
Seo a leanas an rabhadh: “Tá an ceart agat fanacht i do thost ach amháin má theastaíonn uait aon rud a rá. Féadtar an fhaisnéis seo a chur síos i scríbhinn agus a úsáid mar fhianaise”
This is a clear indication of the right to silence enjoyed in most cases by an arrested person in Garda custody
Is léir ón ráiteas seo gur féidir leis an cuid is mó de na daoine faoi choimeád i stáisiún na nGardaí a c(h)eart chun tosta a úsáid
It has been accepted in the High Court in Heaney v Ireland (1994) that the right to silence is set down in Article 38.1 of the Irish Constitution
Taispeánadh san Ard-Chúirt i Heaney v Éire (1994) gur leagadh amach an ceart chun tosta in Alt 38.1 de Bhunreacht na hÉireann
The judge in that case was of the view that the fairness of a criminal trial could be damaged by events that took place prior to it
I dtuairim an bhreithimh, féadtar cur isteach ar chothroime na trialach choiriúil de bharr na n-imeachtaí a tharlaíonn roimh ré
That includes the issue as to whether or not a person being interviewed by the Gardai, before being charged, was afforded his or her right to silence
Cuirtear san áireamh anseo na cearta a bhaineann le h-agallaimh na nGardai, roimh duine a ionchúiseamh, agus leis an ceart chun tosta a chur ar fáil dó nó di
If not then the trial could be compromised and thus would be in breach of Article 38.1 of the Constitution
Muna ndéantar é seo, féadtar an triail a chomhréiteach agus Alt 38.1 den Bhunreacht a shárú
The decision of the High Court in Heaney v Ireland was upheld in the Supreme Court, which affirmed the right to silence in police custody as having a Constitutional Status
Ghlac an Chúirt Uachtarach le cinneadh na hArd-Chúirte maidir le Heaney v Éire. De réir an chinnidh seo, tugtar Stádas Bunreachtúil don cheart chun tosta faoi choimeád
However, the Supreme Court also stated that the Constitutional right to silence only applied to anything that might offer the police evidence, which was self-incriminating
Léiríodh sa Chúirt Uachtarach freisin áfach go mbaineann an ceart bunreachtúil chun tosta le faisnéis féin-ionchoirithe a chabhraíonn leis na Gardaí

In other words the Constitutional right to silence could not extend to not answering police questions that would not involve self-incrimination such as providing your name and address when asked or providing your date of birth or nationality when asked as this information would not normally be self-incriminating

I bhfocail eile, ní bhaineann an ceart chun tosta bunreachtúil le freagra a thabhairt ar cheisteanna neamh-fhéin-ionchoirithe na nGardaí, mar shampla, d’ainm agus do sheoladh a sholáthar dóibh nó do dháta breithe nó náisiúntacht. Ní faisnéis féin-ionchoirithe í seo de ghnáth
The right to silence and privilege against self-incrimination in Ireland is not an absolute right
Níl an ceart chun tosta uathoibríoch ag daoine in Éirinn agus níl pribhléid acu i gcoinne féin-ionchoiriú
However, in the vast majority of criminal offences this right does apply
Baineann an ceart seo leis an cuid is mó de chionta coiriúla áfach

When you are accused of a criminal offence youl enjoy the right to silence unless you are informed by the Gardai that the particular offence for which you are arrested places a certain obligation on you as discussed below

Nuair a dhéantar duine a chúiseamh i leith ciona coiriúil, is féidir leat do cheart chun tosta a chleachtadh ach amháin nuair a chuireann na Gardaí in iúl duit go bhfuil ort an fhianaise a thabhairt don chion áirithe seo mar a luaitear thíos
The Gardai must also inform you of the consequences if you fail to comply
Bíonn ar na Gardai a chur in iúl duit freisin cad a tharlódh má theipeann ort é seo a dhéanamh
Your right to silence at trial
Do cheart chun tosta i dtriail
Bunreacht na hEireann provides the absolute right for someone accused of a criminal offence to refuse to testify
Tugann Bunreacht na hEireann an ceart do dhuine cúisithe i gcion coiriúil a c(h)eart chun tosta a chleachtadh
This right is set down in Article 38.1 of the Constitution
Tá an ceart seo leagtha amach in Alt 38.1 den Bhunreacht

If you decide to testify, or give evidence, then you waive that right and you must answer questions put to you by the prosecution, and cannot refuse to do so on the basis that the answers would incriminate you

Más mian leat dearbhú le rud nó an fhianaise a thabhairt, níl cead agat do cheart chun tosta a chleachtadh agus ní mór duit ceisteanna na gcúisitheoirí a fhreagairt. Ní mór duit é seo a dhéanamh fiú amháin má bhíonn ceisteanna féin-ionchoirithe i gceist
Consequences at trial of remaining silent
Cad a tharlaíonn nuair a ghlacann tú le do cheart chun tosta i dtriail
There are two areas where the law in Ireland impinges on your privilege against self-incrimination and your right to silence:
Tá dhá eisceacht i dlí na hÉireann a chuireann isteach ar do phribhléid i gcoinne féin-ionchoirithe agus ar do cheart chun tosta:
• Questions that allows inferences to be drawn at your trial from your failure to answer certain questions or to provide certain information and
• Ceisteanna a chuireann le tátal a bhaint as do thriail nuair a theipeann ort ceisteanna áirithe a fhreagairt nó faisnéis áirithe a sholáthar agus
• Offences where it is a criminal offence not to answer certain questions or to provide certain information
• Cionta ina ndéantar imeachtaí coiriúla a thionscnamh i do choinne nuair a theipeann ort ceisteanna áirithe a fhreagairt nó faisnéis áirithe a sholáthar
It is important to note that these provisions do not only operate when you are in custody, but they also apply if you are not in Garda custody at the time you are asked the questions

Is tábhachtach é a thabhairt faoi deara freisin go gcuirtear na forálacha seo i bhfeidhm nuair a bhíonn duine faoi choimeád, ach freisin mura mbíonn siad faoi choimeád ag na Gardaí nuair a chuirtear ceisteanna orthu
Inferences to be drawn in certain circumstances
Déantar tátail a bhaint amach i gcásanna áirithe

Under the Criminal Justice Act 1984 as amended by Part 4 of the Criminal Justice Act 2007 inferences can be drawn from your silence in certain circumstances in any proceedings against you for an arrestable offence

Faoin Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 1984, arna leasú ag Cuid 4 den Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 2007, féadtar tátail a bhaint amach mura n-éiríonn leat aon rud a rá nuair a thaifeadtar imeachtaí coiriúla i do choinne de bharr ciona inghabhála
An arrestable offence is an offence for which a person can be imprisoned for 5 years or more
Is cion inghabhála ann ná cion lena mbaineann téarma príosúnachta de 5 bliana ar a laghad

Inferences can be drawn, if at anytime before being charged or when you are charged, or when informed by a Garda that you may be procecuted for the offence, you fail or refuse to account for any object, substance or mark on your person, clothing or in your possession or in any place in which you were when questioned by a Garda

Féadtar tátail a bhaint amach, mura n-éiríonn leat nó má dhiúltaíonn tú ábhar, substaint nó marc ar do chorp, ar d’éadaí nó i do sheilbh nó in aon áit ina raibh tú i láthair a chur in iúl, nuair a chuireann na Gardaí ceist ort roimh choir a chur i do leith nó nuair a dhéantar coir a chur i do leith, nó nuair a chuireann Garda in iúl duit go ndéantar tú a ionchúiseamh
Similarly inferences can be drawn if you fail or refuse to account for your presence at a particular place around the time the offence was committed

Ar an gcuma chéanna, féadtar tátail a bhaint amach má theipeann ort nó má dhiúltaíonn tú a mhíniú do na Gardaí cén fáth go raibh tú i láthair in áit áirithe agus coir á dhéanamh timpeall an ama céanna

The Garda has to have a reasonable belief that the presence of the object, substance or mark, or your presence at the place, has a relevance to your involvement in the offence which has been committed
Ba cheart don Gharda a chreidiúint go bhfuil baint agat leis an gcoir toisc ábhar, substaint nó marc ar do chorp, ar d’éadaí nó i do sheilbh nó in aon áit ina raibh tú i láthair

Inferences may also be drawn if you fail to mention any fact which you then rely on in your defence during the proceedings and which, in the circumstances existing at the time, you could reasonably have been expected to mention when being questioned or charged

Féadtar tátail a bhaint amach chomh maith, mura n-éiríonn leat faisnéis a nochtadh, a úsáidfear mar chosaint dhleathach le linn na n-imeachtaí, faisnéis ba cheart duit a chur in iúl do na Gardaí nuair a chuirtear ceist ort nó nuair a ionchúisítear thú
It is not an offence to fail or refuse to answer such questions
Ní cion é má theipeann ort nó má dhiúltaíonn tú a leithéid de cheisteanna a fhreagairt
However, the court or jury can take into consideration (when deciding on your guilt or innocence) the fact that you had failed or refused to answer the questions when asked by the Gardai

Is féidir leis an gcoiste dháréag é a chur san áireamh áfach (nuair a dhéantar do chiontacht nó do neamhchiontacht a leagadh amach) gur theip ort nó gur dhiúltaigh tú ceisteanna na nGardaí a fhreagairt
If there is no other evidence put to the court or jury then they cannot convict you on the failure or refusal to answer questions alone
Mura mbíonn a thuilleadh faisnéise ar fáil, níl cead ag an Chúirt nó ag an Coiste Dháréag tú a chiontú toisc gur theip ort nó gur dhiúltaigh tú ceisteanna na nGardaí a fhreagairt
It can only be used to strengthen other evidence presented to the court or jury in the case
Féadtar an fhaisnéis seo a úsáid chun an fhianaise a chuirtear i láthair na cúirte nó an choiste dháréag a neartú

It also cannot be used unless the Garda informed you in ordinary, clear, understandable, language what the effect of a failure or refusal might be and you were given a reasonable opportunity to consult a solicitor

Ní fhéadtar í a úsáid má theipeann ar an Garda é a chur in iúl duit i slí soiléir intuigthe, cad a tharlóidh má theipeann ort nó má dhiúltaíonn tú ceisteanna a fhreagairt nó mura dtugtar seans réasúnach duit teagmháil a dhéanamh le haturnae
The questioning must be recorded electronically or you must consent in writing to it not being recorded
Bíonn ar na Gardaí an t-agallamh a chlárú go leictreonach nó do shíniú a fháil roimh ré mura ndéantar é sin

Similarly, under the Criminal Justice Act 2006, as amended by the Criminal Justice (Amendment) Act 2009, inferences may be drawn as the result of the failure, in particular circumstances, to answer questions

Mar an gcéanna, faoin Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil 2006, arna leasú ag an Acht um Cheartas Coiriúil (Leasú) 2009, tátail a tharraingt mar thoradh ar an teip, in imthosca áirithe, chun ceisteanna a fhreagairt
This applies to the organised crime offences under Part 7 of the Act
Baineann sé seo leis na cionta coireachta eagraithe faoi Chuid 7 den Acht
European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms
An Coinbhinsiún Eorpach chun Cearta an Duine agus Saoirsí Bunúsacha a Chosaint

The European Court of Human Rights in John Murray-v-United Kingdom (1996) 22E.H.R.R.29 has considered the issue of adverse inferences and whether or not this is compatible with Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms which guarantees the individual a right to a fair trial

Rinne Cúirt na hEorpa um Chearta an Duine athbhreithniú ar tháthail dhiúltacha i John Murray-v-An Rícht Aontaithe (1996) 22E.H.R.R.29, chun a fháil amach an gcomhlíontar Airteagal 6 den Choinbhinsiún Eorpach chun Cearta an Duine agus Saoirsí Bunúsacha a Chosaint. Forálann an Coinbhinsiún don cheart chun trialach cothroime
The Court ruled that it would be incompatible with the right to silence if a conviction were based solely on the accused’s failure or refusal to answer police questions
Rialaigh an Chúirt go bhfuil an ceart chun tosta ag gach duine agus mar sin de, ní fhéadtar duine a ionchúiseamh má theipeann orthu nó má dhiúltaíonn siad ceisteannana na nGardaí a fhreagairt
It did, however accept the legality of taking an accused’s failure or refusal to answer questions into account in considering the weight or persuasiveness of the prosecution evidence
Ghlac sí áfach le comhar an duine cúisithe ceisteanna na nGardaí a fhreagairt maidir le neart fianaise na gcúisitheoirí

The Court also said that a number of factors would have to be considered in deciding whether or not adverse inferences were in line with the European convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms

Rialaigh an Chúirt chomh maith go gcaithfear roinnt pointí a chur san áireamh roimh tátail dhiúltacha a leagadh amach mar ghníomhaíochtaí a chomhlíonann An Coinbhinsiún Eorpach chun Cearta an Duine agus Saoirsí Bunúsacha a Chosaint
Chief among these were:
Is iad seo a leanas na príomhphointí:
• Whether or not the appropriate warnings had been given to the accused as to the effect of remaining silent
• Cibé go bhfuair an duine cúisithe faisnéis faoi cad a tharlódh mura ndéantar ceisteanna a fhreagairt, nó nach bhfuair
• Whether the accused understood such warnings
• Cibé go raibh an duine cúisithe in ann na rabhaidh sin a thuiscint, nó nach raibh
• Whether or not the accused had access to legal advice
• Cibé go raibh an duine cúisithe in ann comhairle dhleathach a rochtain, nó nach raibh
• The fairness and reasonableness of the inference which were actually drawn by the court
• Cothroime agus réasúntacht na dtátal a leagadh amach sa chúirt
Offence of not answering questions
Cad a tharlaíonn nuair a theipeann ar dhuine ceisteanna a fhreagairt

The second area that impinges on your privilege against self-incrimination and your right to silence is that which makes it an offence if you fail to answer certain questions or to provide certain information

Cuirtear isteach freisin ar do cheart chun tú féin a chosaint i gcoinne féin-ionchoirithe agus ar do cheart chun tosta nuair a fhaightear duine ciontach i gcion, mura n-éiríonn leo ceisteanna áirithe a fhreagairt nó faisnéis áirithe a sholáthar
The most important piece of criminal law in Ireland in this regard is the Offences Against the State Act 1939
Is é an dlí is tábhachtaí in Éirinn maidir leis an saincheist seo ná an tAcht um Chiontaí in Aghaidh an Stáit 1939
The greatest powers given to the Gardai are in this piece of law
Tugann an dlí seo cumhachtaí tábhachtacha do na Gardaí
The provisions contained in the Act in question apply whether or not an accused person was in Garda custody at the time the questions were asked
De réir forálacha an Achta seo, ba cheart go mbeadh duine i stáisiún na nGardaí nuair a bhí ceisteanna á chur air/uirthi
However, it is of most relevance when a person is in Garda custody
Baineann an tAcht seo le daoine atá faoi choimeád i stáisiún na nGardaí ach go háirithe

Section 52 of the Offences against the State Act 1939 obliges you if detained under Section 30 of the Act to answer certain questions concerning your movements and actions and your knowledge concerning the commission of any offence under the Act

Nuair a bhíonn tú faoi choimeád i stáisiún na nGardaí faoi Alt 30 den Acht um Chiontaí in Aghaidh an Stáit 1939, bíonn ort ceisteanna áirithe a fhreagairt maidir le do ghluaiseachtaí agus do ghníomhaíochtaí, agus aon eolas atá agat ar chion faoin Acht seo, de réir Ailt 52 den Acht
Before requesting this information, the Garda must inform you that the request is being made under section 52 of the Act
Roimh ceist a chur ort faoin eolas seo, bíonn ar an Garda a chur in iúl duit go ndéanfar an t-iarratas faoi alt 52 den Acht
You must then be informed of the consequences of a failure or refusal to comply with the request, that is, you are committing an offence
Ní mór don Gharda a chur in iúl duit cad a tharlóidh má theipeann ort an t-eolas seo a sholáthar dóibh nó má dhéantar an t-iarratas a dhiúltú, sé sin go bhfuil tú freagrach as cion
The Garda must explain this in clear, ordinary and understandable language
Ní mór don Gharda é seo a chur in iúl duit i slí soiléir intuigthe

The European Court of Human Rights in Quinn-v-Ireland (2001) 33 E.H.R.R.264, while acknowledging that the right to silence and the right not to incriminate oneself as laid out in Article 6 of the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms was not an absolute right, it felt that section 52 went further than was necessary to meet the needs of the state

Cheap Cúirt na hEorpa um Chearta an Duine i Quinn-v-Éire (2001) 33 E.H.R.R.264, gur cuireadh alt 52 i bhfeidhm i slí ró-dhoimhin chun riachtanais an stáit a chomhlíonadh. Ag an am céanna, admhaíonn an Chúirt nach bhfuil an ceart uathoibríoch ag daoine chun tosta agus i gcoinne féin-ionchoirithe mar atá leagtha amach in Alt 6 den Choinbhinsiún Eorpach chun Cearta an Duine agus Saoirsí Bunúsacha a Chosaint

However, it seems from more recent decisions of the courts in Ireland that once any such evidence relating to a failure or refusal under section 52 is not used in the prosecution case against the accused then it will be accepted by the courts

Is léir ó na cinntí is déanaí a glacadh leo sna cúirteanna in Éirinn áfach, go ndéanfar glacadh le fianaise a thaispeánann gur theip ar dhuine ceisteanna a fhreagairt nó gur dhiúltaigh siad ceisteanna a fhreagairt mura n-úsáidtear an t-eolas seo i gcoinne an duine cúisithe
In other words, the evidence of failure or refusal can only be given when prosecuting an accused for an offence under section 52
Is é sin a rá ná go gcaithfear duine a ionchúiseamh i leith ciona, faoi alt 52, chun a thaispeáint gur theip orthu ceisteanna a fhreagairt nó gur dhiúltaigh siad ceisteanna a fhreagairt
